data.title: Good to walk through!
data.text:
It was raining the afternoon we had planned to walk through the Hawaii State Capitol grounds. You can walk through it anytime as there are no doors that enclose the front and back. Father Damien statue (Priest from Belgium) that helped saved the leprosy colony in Kalaupapa is in the front on S Beretania St. and a replica of the Liberty Bell is beside it.
Walking through the capitol, it is open air from the top with a round mosaic tile ground that resembles water or the sea. This leads to the back where the statue of Queen Liuluikalani (last queen of Hawaii ) is located.  You can head up to the roof top for views of Honolulu and surrounding area during the normal weekday working hours.
Great place to stroll through.  Need to pay parking meters if you are arriving by own vehicle otherwise, public transportation is readily available.

data.title: Interesting Architecture
data.text: A nice building and interesting story behind the architecture of the building. I would recommend a visit if you are in the area.

data.title: Beautiful 60's Style Archtecture - Legislature is Here
data.text: The Hawaii Senate meets here and the Governor's Office is here as well. When not is session I believe you can visit. Check the website. On the left of Beretania St on the way downtown.

data.title: Beautiful architecture, functional spot
data.text: The Hawai'i Capitol is a great building that is not your typical Capitol/government building.  Built using modern Hawaiian architecture, the building has a lot of symbolism and is on the grounds of the Iolani Palace.

data.title: Unusual state building.
data.text:
Unlike most state building there are no columns, dome or marble stairs. Surrounded by a moat representing the ocean and supported by two cones reminding one of the volcanoes that formed the Hawaiian Islands. The building is sort and square almost floating in air.
The manicured grounds are nice to walk around.
Tours are available.

data.title: Light and airy.
data.text: Set in attractive gardens and full of Hawaiin symbolism, this is  a pleasant and peaceful place to visit.

data.title: Unique State Capitol Building
data.text:
This is one of the most, if not the most, unique state capitol buildings in the US.  Its open air-style is befitting for Hawaii and is also supposed to remind you of a volcano.

We only got a chance to walk through and around the exterior as the doors leading inside were locked.  The building is near Iolani Palace and makes a good stop after touring the palace.  Don't forget to check out the Banyan trees nearby.

data.title: Interesting architecture, in need of attention!
data.text: We did not tour the inside the building, instead just walked around and enjoyed the very interesting design. It needs some attention as this type of design if not kept fresh will look dated quickly.

data.title: Unusual State Capitol
data.text: The building has an unusual shape for a state capitol.  The architecture does fit with the area and culture. It helps to learn more about the area by visiting this venue.

data.title: The famous State Building as seen on Jack Lord's Hawaii five-O
data.text: Driving through Downtown Honolulu you can see allot on Beretania Street and King Street too! However, the State Capital Building is unmistakable with that mote around it.

data.title: Large oversized state builiding
data.text: Interesting that this large square building represents the best of island culture. It is interesting in that you can walk through and underneath. Good spot to get your bearings and then keep going.

data.title: Amazing
data.text: Totally different than any other state capitol I've been too. Small, compact...but full of history. You could almost drive by it without noticing. I love history and it would not have been a complete tour without going here.

data.title: 50th State Capitol
data.text:
Hawai'i became the 50th state on August 21, 1959. The capital was completed in 1969 at a cost of $25 million. As you can guess, the building serves as the center of our state government, but it's the architecture of the building that I want to talk about. The building is surrounded by water - this is symbolic of the Pacific Ocean surrounding Hawai'i. Look at the base of the building both left and right - the base looks like a volcano which is how the islands were formed. Next you see eight pillars - these symbolize the eight major islands of Hawai'i plus at the top they form what looks like palm tree's. At 7,500 pounds and 15 feet in
diameter - the State Seal is in the middle of the building's face. On the seal you will find the State Motto "Ua Mau Ke Ea O Ka Aina I Ka Pono" which means "The life of the land is  perpetuated in righteousness". The state motto is from King Kamehameha III's words upon receiving the throne of Hawai'i back from England in 1843. Also, inside the building there is a
mosaic in the middle of the floor - called "Aquarius" its different shades of blue represent the Pacific Ocean.
To get there, you can drive and there is a fare amount of parking ear by.  OR, there are several buses that pass by as it a major transfer point.

data.title: Don't miss a walk through our capitol building!
data.text: If you are anywhere near downtown Honolulu, a stop at the Capitol building is a must!  There are capitol tours if you are interested. However, the great thing is that one can walk all through the building on your own.  On the 4th floor, there is a room for public access and help if needed about legislative issues.  The Governor's office is on the 5th floor.  From the 5th floor, there are beautiful views of the city.  Mountains on one side, the ocean on the other.  If the legislature is in session, you can go in and see them in session as well.  The design is open and if you have time, some of the legislators have local art in their offices as well.    Be sure to stop and aloha Queen Liliuokalani's statue.    Don't miss a stop at the Capitol.

data.title: Capitol #48
data.text: This was the 48th state capitol we've visited. It had a nice open design, but though we were there when the capitol was supposed to be open, there were only locked doors on the ground floor! We finally, in desperation, tried the elevator, and found the same until the top floor, where the offices of the lieutenant governor and governor were open. The people in the latter were VERY helpful, explaining the pictures on the walls, taking our picture behind the governor's ceremonial desk. They saved the visit, which otherwise would have been very disappointing.

data.title: Interesting place to visit
data.text: It's worth a stop here to see the building architecture and view the Queen Lili'uokalani Statue. Last Queen in Hawaii. She also wrote their national anthem On the day we visited there were many happy people who just became citizens, smiling and waiving there certificates.

data.title: Interesting Capitol Building
data.text: Directly next to Iolani Palace the capitol building is an interesting design with an open courtyard and assembly halls on each side. The fountains seem to need repair but over all an impressive building.

data.title: Interesting architecture
data.text: Worth a visit. Interesting building to look at and learn more about why it was built the way it was. Wish I had taken a guided tour, but time-wise could not.

data.title: morden style state house
data.text: Makes a nice photo op but offers little more of real interest to the visitor. Its a real deperature from the mainland capitiols in style

data.title: The 25th best state capitol I've visited
data.text:
And I've visited 25. 

First, the homeless people. They're everywhere. If pointing that out makes me cruel and heartless, then you give them food and cigarettes and money and leave me out of it. 

Second, the capitol itself has no discernible place for visitors. Every other state capitol I've visited makes the house chambers available for viewing when the legislature is not in session. Not here. The chambers were hard to find, too. You have to go underground to access them, but either way, they're not going to let you in. 

I was hoping to learn something of the history of the state. Again, every other state capitol has guided tours. And tourism information. And brief histories of the state. And pictures of the previous legislatures and governors throughout the years. Hawaii's has just 2 identical photos of the current legislature, and nothing else. The walls are mostly unadorned, except for a few kids' drawings of peace signs and other stuff. 

The building was constructed in the 1960s, and looks it. Rectangular and impractical, with offices along the perimeter and literally nothing in the middle (just empty space with no roof.) I felt like I was in the world's most depressing office building. I should've gone to the beach instead.
